subject: Re: [junit] Re: Scope of the unit test case
msgSnippet: ... It s only my opinion, but what I observe teams writing some end-to-end tests, but not nearly enough, and finding some integration defects, but not nearly
messageBody:
On Feb 24, 2008, at 14:25 , Robert Wenner wrote:

> On Thursday 21 February 2008 09:08, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > The two are similar enough to call them the same for now. I have
> found
> > through years of practice that end-to-end tests are ineffective at
> > finding integration defects caused by incorrect understanding of the
> > contract between pairs of objects.
>
> Interesting.
> I thought end to end tests would be more likely to find integration
> defects, though I agree they may not be the most efficient way.
>
It's only my opinion, but what I observe teams writing some end-to-end
tests, but not nearly enough, and finding some integration defects,
but not nearly enough. In particular, they have, say, 30 instances of
the same integration defect--effectively duplicates--and find about 25
of them. They don't know the other 5 are lurking until a customer
points it out.

I believe that the less we rely on end-to-end tests, the less we'd
allow ourselves to duplicate high-level structures, and therefore the
fewer integration defects we'd have. This would make end-to-end tests
all the less valuable.
> > I use a design technique based on
> > collaboration tests and contract tests that drive out integration
> > defects without integration tests, but it took me a few years of TDD
> > practice before I felt comfortable with the technique. It's not for
> > beginners.
>
> Did you write that up in a blog or article and do you have a link for
> that?
> You could protect it with a TDD adult check somehow so that
> beginners are
> protected from TDD-adult only content...
>
I haven't written it up in that fashion yet, in part because I feel
like I'd mostly be duplicating content from mockobjects.com and I
don't see the point in duplicating work that I know exists. That said,
I describe the technique as the centerpiece of my Test-Driven
Enterprise Code tutorials (Agile 2005-2006, XP 2006-2007, various
other conferences) and it would be a TDD clinic if Agile 2008 accepts
it.

Someday, I'll write it in a book. Maybe.

Take care.
